root.title: HTML Concepts
root.content:
HTML Concepts

Understanding core HTML concepts is crucial for building accessible, well-structured, and search-engine-optimized web pages.

semantic-html.title: Semantic HTML
semantic-html.content:
Semantic HTML

Using HTML tags that accurately describe the content they hold. For example, using <nav> for navigation links, <article> for a blog post, and <footer> for the page footer, instead of using generic <div> tags for everything. This improves accessibility and SEO.

forms.title: Forms & Input
forms.content:
Forms & Input

HTML forms are used to collect user input. Key elements include <form>, <input> (with various types like 'text', 'password', 'checkbox'), <textarea>, and <button>. Proper use of labels and input types is essential for usability.

accessibility.title: Accessibility (a11y)
accessibility.content:
Accessibility (a11y)

Designing web pages so that people with disabilities can use them. In HTML, this includes using 'alt' text for images (<img alt='description'>), using semantic tags correctly, and ensuring keyboard navigability.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of the 'alt' attribute on an tag?
options: To provide a caption below the image
To style the image with CSS
quiz.answer: To provide a text description for screen readers
